abstract.p: Critical illness dramatically increases muscle proteolysis and more than doubles the dietary protein requirement. Yet surprisingly, most critically ill patients receive less than half the recommended amount of protein during their stay in a modern intensive care unit. What could explain the wide gap between the recommendations in clinical care guidelines and actual clinical practice? We suggest that an important aspect of the problem is the failure of guidelines to explain the pathophysiology of protein-energy malnutrition and the ways critical illness modifies protein metabolism. The difficulty created by the lack of a framework for reasoning about appropriate protein provision in critical illness is compounded by the many ambiguous and often contradictory ways the word malnutrition is used in the critical care literature. Failing to elucidate these matters, the recommendations for protein provision in the guidelines are incoherent, unconvincing, and easy to ignore.

body.p: Muscle proteolysis dramatically increases in critical illness, making free amino acids available for new protein synthesis at sites of tissue injury and at other locations in the body to regulate inflammatory and immune responses. The rate of muscle protein loss exceeds the gain of proteins elsewhere, and amino acid catabolism and urea synthesis increase greatly, turning body nitrogen balance strongly negative. Turnover studies indicate that amino acid uptake by the rapidly turning-over central proteins (liver and other splanchnic organs, bone marrow and immunologically active tissues) is constrained by the rate at which amino acids are released from muscle, suggesting that exogenous protein replacement could beneficially increase central protein synthesis, possibly moderate the intensity of systemic inflammation, and improve clinical outcomes in many situations.1-3 There is strong support in the critical care literature for early and adequate protein provision1-3 and virtually universal agreement that critically ill patients need much more protein than healthy people.1-9

Thus, although healthy people require an average of 0.6 g/kg body weight per day (the safe level is 0.8 g/kg), the most common recommendation for critically ill patients is 1.5 g/kg of normal dry body weight per day.10 A recent systematic review of the clinical evidence indicates that most critically ill patients could actually require considerably more than 1.5 g protein/kg,11 a conclusion that is strengthened by subsequently identified or published evidence.12,13

Given the acknowledged importance of generous protein provision, why do critically ill patients receive less than half the most common formal recommendation for protein provision during their stay in a modern intensive care unit (ICU)?14,15 In our view, an important aspect of the problem is the failure of critical care nutrition guidelines to explain the pathophysiology and clinical manifestations of protein-energy malnutrition, its clinical implications, and the ways critical illness modifies protein metabolism. The difficulty created by the lack of a physiologically coherent framework for reasoning about critical care nutrition is worsened by the many ambiguous and sometimes contradictory ways the word malnutrition is used in the critical care literature. Failing to elucidate these matters, the recommendations for protein and energy provision in the guidelines are incoherent and unconvincing and hence easy to ignore.

sec.title: Protein-Energy Malnutrition in Adult Critical Illness
sec.p: Prolonged protein and energy deficiency eventually culminates in the disease variously known as protein-energy malnutrition, protein-calorie malnutrition,16 and starvation disease.17 The cardinal signs of this disease are generalized muscle atrophy and adipose tissue depletion. The detrimental clinical features of protein-energy malnutrition emerge when the body’s protein reserve, skeletal muscle,18 has been depleted enough to impair specific biochemical, physiological, and immunological functions.17 Nonetheless, survival is common in uncomplicated moderate protein-energy malnutrition, thanks to an adaptive reduction in energy expenditure by the metabolically active lean tissues, a decrease in the total lean tissue mass, and increased efficiency of endogenous protein turnover and dietary protein retention, all of which enable energy and protein homeostasis to be restored despite the continuing inadequacy of dietary protein and energy. But critical illness prevents this adaptation: it increases energy expenditure and stimulates net protein breakdown, precipitating a rapid and potentially lethal depletion of the body’s protein and energy reserves.17,19-21 Appropriate micronutrient provision is also important in critical care and specifically relevant to the prevention and treatment of protein-energy malnutrition, since deficiencies of several micronutrients impair protein anabolism.17

Very low body weight—typically identified as a body mass index (BMI) less than ~18 kg/m2—is a key component of most tools used to screen for adult protein-energy malnutrition.22 Actually, a BMI as low 18 is compatible with normal health, but in the setting of catabolic illness, it indicates a dangerously low muscle and fat reserve.17 The determinant of survival in protein-energy malnutrition is the body’s active lean tissue mass, also referred to as the body cell mass.17,23 This compartment—approximately 80% of which is skeletal muscle—normally accounts for 45%–50% of a young adult’s total body weight.18 BMI predicts muscle mass reasonably well when values of BMI range between subnormal and normal, but the predictive value of BMI becomes increasingly unreliable as it increases above normal,21 particularly in old age, in which obesity and age-related muscle atrophy (sarcopenia) frequently coexist.24-27 The relationship between BMI and the lean tissue compartment is especially problematic in critical illness because systemic inflammation, sodium retention, and fluid resuscitation artificially increase body weight (and hence BMI), and a large proportion of critically ill patients are elderly, obese, and sarcopenic.28

Subjective global assessment (SGA) is a formalization of the narrative process used by skilled clinicians to diagnose protein-energy malnutrition.29-31 SGA involves a consideration of historical and clinical evidence of recent and ongoing inadequate protein and energy consumption or increased protein catabolism, together with a targeted physical examination, the most important findings of which are loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting.29 After completing the data-gathering process, the assessor intuitively diagnoses the patient as having no “malnutrition” (A), possible mild “malnutrition” (B), or severe (manifest) “malnutrition” (C). From the narrative perspective, SGA-C may be considered as diagnostic of protein-energy malnutrition, SGA-A as excluding the diagnosis, and SGA-B as a gray zone that encompasses the possibility of mild or inconsequential existing protein-energy malnutrition, with the suspicion that protein-energy malnutrition could develop in the future if conditions do not improve.

Mid-arm or forearm circumference measurements provide important information about the body’s muscle mass, and when sufficiently below normal, they may be used to identify protein-energy malnutrition.32-37 But the technique requires training and skill,37,38 and an evaluation of the body’s entire muscle mass that relies on a circumferential or caliper measurement of one part of a patient’s arm can be problematic in the presence of overhydration and obesity.39-42 These practical considerations argue in favor of the ease and narrative coherence of SGA, involving as it does an attentive, qualitative physical examination of muscle mass at several locations, including the head, neck, shoulders, and hands, areas of the body that are usually less affected by obesity and overhydration than the limbs and trunk.43

This description of the nutrition pathophysiology of critical illness suggests that either SGA or reliable muscle-mass anthropometry ought to predict adverse clinical outcomes attributable to protein-energy malnutrition at least as accurately as currently more popular indicators such as a history of weight loss, inadequate calorie intake, or hypoalbuminemia, none of which are specific to the existing state of the body’s protein reserve. Bearing in mind the caveat that in critical illness, generous or excessive subcutaneous adipose tissue is no guarantee of an adequate muscle mass, the limited data available to test this hypothesis tend to support it.39-41,44-47 The evaluation of muscle mass and the clinical implications of its depletion are underresearched areas in critical care nutrition.27 Preliminary studies suggest the usefulness of ultrasound or radiographic measurements of muscle mass to validate or complement simple bedside techniques such as SGA.42,48,49 (These suggestions do not reduce the usefulness of a history of weight loss, inadequate food intake, or hypoalbuminemia as indicators of the possibility or future risk of protein-energy malnutrition.)

sec.title: What Is Malnutrition?
sec.p: Protein-energy malnutrition is almost universally referred to in the critical care literature simply as malnutrition. Unfortunately, this same word is widely used to describe any disease caused by any kind of inadequate nutrition and, indeed, any diet that increases the risk of developing any disease—for this is, after all, the implied meaning of mal-nutrition. The confusion created by this ambiguous language is worsened by a plethora of screening tools that claim to identify “malnutrition” from the total score on a checklist, without distinguishing between screening and diagnosis.22 (The aim of a screening test is to identify potential cases of a disease, the diagnosis of which is then definitively considered. Good screening tests are easy to use and sensitive enough to capture almost all true cases of the disease, but they are not required to be highly specific.) The main reason why the prevalence of “malnutrition” reportedly varies from 13%–78% in acute-care hospitals appears to be the large number of different definitions of malnutrition used to generate the statistics.50 Growing appreciation of the damaging effect of this terminological confusion on the credibility of nutrition science has spurred experts in Europe and North America to recommend the adoption of clear, etiology-based diagnostic terminology.51-53 “Etiology-based” diagnosis is a diagnosis that is embedded in a well-defined pathophysiological paradigm.54

At present, the critical care guidelines of the American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (A.S.P.E.N.) define protein-energy malnutrition as recent weight loss of more than 10%–15% or current body weight that is <90% of “ideal.”55 If a BMI of 23 is considered ideal, then according to A.S.P.E.N., any patient whose BMI is <21 has protein-energy malnutrition. But protein-energy malnutrition is a disease, not a number. The A.S.P.E.N. definition of protein-energy malnutrition is actually a screening maneuver, and a very insensitive one, because it misses obese patients with protein-energy malnutrition. When designing a clinical trial to determine clinical outcomes resulting from following the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines, Casaer et al56 chose a very different definition of malnutrition—namely, a BMI <17. (Aberrant as this definition may seem, it is very close to the definition of serious malnutrition used by the American College of Chest Physicians—namely, a BMI <16.20) There is no doubt that a patient whose BMI is <17 has protein-energy malnutrition. But screening tests should not aim for specificity. In the end, only 1.2% of the patients evaluated for enrollment by Casaer et al56 were classified as having “malnutrition.”56

There is much literature about the prevalence of protein-energy malnutrition in adult critical illness, but the published articles are frequently flawed by conceptual and methodological errors. For example, in contrast to Casaer et al,56 it is frequently claimed in the literature that nearly half of critically ill patients are “malnourished.”57-60 One widely cited article reported that 50% of critically ill patients are malnourished, with malnutrition being defined in the article as subnormal serum albumin concentration plus subnormal body weight.61 This definition is highly problematic since hypoalbuminemia is characteristic of critical illness itself, even in the absence of any malnutrition, and roughly half the people in most populations weigh less than average.

Another widely cited article reported an association between malnutrition (defined as “calorie underprovision”) and adverse clinical outcomes in critically ill patients.62 The authors presumably reasoned that calorie underprovision eventually leads to protein-energy malnutrition and its complications. This reasoning appears to have led them (and many other authors who observed similar associations6,14,63-68) to conclude that calorie underprovision worsens clinical outcomes in critical illness.69-71

But this interpretation must be considered dubious. “Calorie malnutrition” cannot explain the observed adverse outcomes because the fat reserve of the great majority of the patients enrolled in these studies was normal or excessive. No biological paradigm exists to explain how simple calorie underprovision could cause the adverse clinical outcomes attributed to it in these articles. For example, a continuously negative calorie balance of 1000 kcal/d for 4 weeks would diminish a patient’s adipose tissue mass enough to reduce his or her BMI from 27 to 26, or from 24 to 23, or from 23 to 22 kg/m2. Why is that a problem?

It turns out that all of the observational data cited in the literature as proof that calorie underprovision causes adverse clinical outcomes are confounded by unwarranted causal inference. Sicker patients plainly have a worse prognosis, and the same forces that make them sicker conspire to make them more difficult to feed.72-74 To a large and indeterminate extent, greater disease severity reduces calorie provision, not the reverse. This sobering conclusion in no way refutes the plausibility of the notion that “malnutrition” can indeed seriously worsen clinical outcomes. The most reasonable scenario is a downward causal spiral of worsening “malnutrition” and worsening clinical status.74,75 But what kind of malnutrition is involved in this downward spiral? It cannot be “calorie underprovision,” because there is no cogent physiological mechanism by which simple negative energy balance could worsen outcomes in fat-replete patients.

What about protein deficiency? The biological and metabolic evidence that dietary protein lack induces and worsens protein-energy malnutrition is vast, and the clinical evidence that generous protein provision to critically ill patients can mitigate or arrest body protein loss, and possibly improve clinical outcomes, although limited, is consistently promising.11 It appears from the tone of the literature that a scientifically unwarranted preoccupation with calories has diverted the attention of investigators from the far greater importance of early and sufficient protein provision in critical illness. (Since energy and protein are usually provided in a constant ratio,14,15,66,67,76 observations that link short-term calorie underprovision to adverse outcomes could actually have some predictive value: calorie underprovision is a strong indicator of protein [and micronutrient] underprovision.68,77)

sec.title: Effects of Protein and Energy Provision on Body Protein Economy
sec.p: In the early years of nutrition support, macronutrient provision was considered to be indicated for most critically ill patients, including patients without protein-energy malnutrition at the onset of their critical illness. Patients who were experiencing only moderate catabolic stress and whose muscle mass was adequate were considered less of a priority than patients with protein-energy malnutrition who were experiencing intense catabolic stress.32,78 It has long been known that the rate of energy provision strongly affects body protein retention,79 and for this reason, parenteral nutrition (PN)—then called “hyperalimentation”—was routinely enriched with high-energy dextrose to boost the protein-anabolic effect of the infused amino acids.9,80,81 Given the short time course of most critical illness, preservation of body fat was a secondary consideration that came into play only in prolonged illness. It soon became clear, however, that overfeeding either with carbohydrate1,82 or fat83 is toxic in critical illness. In the modern era, energy overfeeding is regarded as so toxic that even when the formal therapeutic goal is to match calorie provision to energy expenditure, available methods for estimating this target are so imprecise79,84-86 (and the patient’s fat reserve usually so generous) that prudence dictates erring on the side of energy underfeeding.9

The relationship between energy provision and body protein retention is rather well characterized, both in catabolically stressed and nonstressed patients.11,79,87-93 When protein provision is kept constant and sufficient, nitrogen balance continually improves as energy provision increases up to ~50% of energy expenditure. Thereafter, further increases in energy provision lead to only slight further improvements in nitrogen balance,94 especially in critical illness,4,92,95 and with increasing toxicity. A minimum amount of energy may be important in critical illness,96 but it is unlikely to exceed 50% of energy expenditure (it might be considerably less than this) as long as protein provision is increased enough to compensate for the impairment of protein retention created by the hypocaloric state.79 Experts who are aware of this evidence recommend limiting calorie provision to ~15 kcal/kg normal dry body weight per day in patients whose fat reserve is adequate97; one of us has recommended that calorie provision not exceed around two-thirds of energy expenditure when the fat reserve is adequate, with the proviso that protein provision must be suitably generous.1,82 For example, the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines stipulate that hypocalorically fed patients require at least 2.0 g protein/kg ideal body weight per day.11,98,99

sec.title: Physiological Paradigms in Evidence-Based Medicine
sec.p: In a historically important article that introduced evidenced-based medicine (EBM) to the medical community, EBM was described as a new paradigm of medical practice that places the emphasis of clinical decision making on the most reliable available clinical evidence.100 The notion of scientific paradigms was introduced by Thomas Kuhn101 in his groundbreaking analysis of the role of paradigms in science. In fact, the practice paradigm of EBM is embedded in a conceptual paradigm based on biology and pathophysiology, from which it derives its postulates, assumptions, and valuations. The essence of Kuhn’s insight is that in science, evidence is necessary but not sufficient. Evidence is always interpreted within the framework of a conceptual paradigm.

A paradigm is a conceptual structure that attempts to make sense of observations within a particular discipline according to an agreed-upon set of postulates, provisional assumptions, and valuations.101 A paradigm’s framework is filled in by data, which both inform the paradigm and are interpreted within it. The more convincing the totality of the evidence that supports a paradigm, the more confidence clinicians can have in using it to extrapolate from the observations in specific clinical trials to actual practice.

The mere existence of a paradigm does not justify a therapy. The crucial requirement is sufficient reliable evidence.100,102 Well-designed and executed randomized clinical trials (RCTs) usually provide the most persuasive evidence, because they usually offer the most reliable way to minimize bias in data acquisition and analysis. RCTs in which this structural bias is effectively minimized are said to have “internal validity.” In general, clinical evidence is considered high quality when it meets the following criteria: internal validity, consistency, precision, relevance to the actual clinical situation (directness or “external validity”), and lack of censorship by reader, reporting, or publication bias.103-106

Many situations arise in which the available evidence supports a particular therapy so conclusively that proceeding to RCTs would be unjustified or even unethical. For example, assertions that cigarette avoidance (or parachute use to prevent major trauma due to gravitational challenge107) are “unproven” because no RCT has verified them demonstrate a misunderstanding of the nature of scientific reasoning. But there is a more profound underlying question: what kind and amount of non-RCT evidence is necessary to accept a particular therapy as scientifically established?

Entering further into the so-called gray zone of EBM,108 how do clinicians decide which of 2 therapeutic options is the more scientifically appropriate to propose to their patients when—as is commonly the case—conclusive evidence is lacking one way or the other? They do so by means of paradigm-embedded reasoning and judgment. Investigators use the same process to decide when more evidence is needed, how much more, and what kind of evidence will settle an issue.74

Paradigms are essential for scientific reasoning, but they can also be wrong. As with experimental evidence, paradigms have to be scrutinized with regard to their internal validity (biological coherence and plausibility, logical rigor, and internally consistent high-quality data) and external validity (relevance and compatibility with the evidence and with other related valid paradigms). Data are building blocks in the framework of paradigms, and, as Kuhn explained, the important work of science is to identify the weakest building blocks, then stress test them with critical experiments. It is a cardinal principle of EBM that strong and convincing evidence trumps a biologically plausible rationale.100,109 When reliable data contradict a paradigm, it has to be modified or replaced by a better one: the paradigm has to shift.

Although praiseworthy in a great many respects, both A.S.P.E.N. and the European Society for Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism (formerly European Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition) guidelines err by asserting that reasoning, opinion, and judgment are a category of evidence, and they err further by relegating it to the lowest level of reliability. Insight, judgment, and opinion are not data: they are conclusions derived from data.110-112 This important semantic fact has been endorsed by the American College of Chest Physicians, the American Thoracic Society, and the Society of Critical Care Medicine.113 Failure to appreciate it can foster the aberrant notion that data somehow stand on their own as the sole determinant of clinical practice, independent of reasoning and judgment. In reality, there is always a paradigm: scientific reasoning requires it. Denying that paradigms matter simply makes them implicit, shielding them from scrutiny.

sec.title: Three Examples of Nutrition Paradigms in Critical Care Medicine
sec.p: Unaware that calorie underfeeding increases the protein requirement, the authors of an otherwise meticulously conducted meta-analysis of RCTs of “permissive underfeeding” in critical illness114 failed to consider the confounding effect of variations in protein provision. The studies included in the final meta-analysis were unacceptably heterogeneous, since provision of the crucial nutrient, protein, varied from generous to almost zero.

It is extremely implausible that a nutrition regimen that is grossly deficient both in protein and energy (“permissive underfeeding”) could be closely similar in its metabolic and clinical consequences to intentional calorie restriction that is appropriately compensated for by a large increase in protein provision (“hypocaloric nutrition”).9 The limited clinical data available suggest that gross protein deficiency can be tolerated for brief periods after uncomplicated major surgery but not when a catabolic complication occurs.115-117 One would be tempted to question the ethics of conducting clinical trials that involve grossly protein-deficient nutrient regimens, if it were not for the fact that such designs are consistent with the standard of care recommended in the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines, and they have been used and defended in recent large clinical trials.11,118 Nonetheless, it is remotely conceivable that adequate protein provision does not significantly improve clinical outcomes. If that was eventually determined to be the case, the biologically naive implicit paradigm assumed by the authors of this meta-analysis would be vindicated, but only then.

Glutamine is a participant in the body’s rapidly interexchanging pool of nonessential free amino acids, which also includes alanine, glycine, aspartate, and glutamate. The nonessential free amino acid pool is replenished by an influx of nitrogen from the catabolic pathways of >90% of all endogenous and exogenous amino acids, and it empties into the urea synthesis pathway by virtue of the finely regulated hepatic enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase. When investigators consider the potential benefits of glutamine supplementation in critical illness, the doses of glutamine they administer in clinical trials have to be commensurate with the endogenous glutamine production rate from whole-body net protein catabolism.119 Allowance also should be made, in data analysis, for endogenous glutamine production by the patients enrolled in clinical trials, which can be roughly assessed by measuring urinary urea excretion. It is virtually a foregone conclusion that clinical trials in which the glutamine dose is physiologically trivial will be negative. Clinical trials that lack such biological internal validity should be censored from meta-analyses.120

There is controversy in the literature over the proper roles of enteral nutrition (EN) and PN in critical illness.121 There is general—but not universal122—agreement that adequate nutrition should be provided early in critical illness. Where the controversy centers is on the role of PN in patients for whom EN is technically feasible but, for a variety of reasons, is failing to meet a patient’s nutrition goal.121 One view is that head-to-head RCTs demonstrate that PN is inherently riskier than EN (even though a mortality difference cannot be shown) and hence should not be used to supplement EN until after as many as 10 days of failed EN.55,123 The other view is that the adverse consequences of serious nutrition insufficiency during the most catabolic phase of critical illness usually outweigh the increased risk (if there indeed is any) of using PN to make up the nutrient shortfall.7,124 Supporters of the latter view argue that PN appears to increase risk only when it creates a state of calorie overfeeding, with its associated consequences of hyperinsulinemic hyperglycemia.28,81 This debate is far from trivial, because, on average, critically ill patients who receive EN alone are severely protein deprived for at least the first week or two in an ICU.

This controversy can be interpreted in different ways,121,125-127 but it is helpful to analyze it in terms of paradigms. According to the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines, the route of administration fully characterizes any form of nutrition therapy: every dose and composition of PN is equivalent to every other one, as well as to every dose and composition of EN. In reality, there can be enormous differences in composition and dose among different PN regimens and between PN and EN.121,128 The upside of PN is that amino acids can be provided within 24–48 hours of admission at an adequate dose of 1.8 g/kg/d (equivalent to 1.5 g/kg/d of intact protein129); its downside is the technical ease of toxic energy overfeeding. By contrast, conventional EN commonly fails to exceed 50% of a patient’s protein goal even after a week or longer of administration and hence virtually guarantees serious protein deprivation.59 It is technically easy to engineer PN to deliver mixed amino acids at a suitably generous rate without calorie overfeeding, whereas, at present, few if any enteral products have been shown to be capable of promptly delivering suitably generous amounts of protein to critically ill patients without simultaneously delivering excess calories.

When reasoning from a biologically informed paradigm, the strongest conclusion allowed by the existing evidence is that overfeeding by PN is riskier than underfeeding by EN. Ultimately, however, a telling argument can be made in favor of a biologically simplistic paradigm that distinguishes PN from EN solely on the basis of their route of administration, namely, external validity. To the extent that critical care specialists actually believe that all nutrition therapies differ only in their route of administration, the oversimplified paradigm has pragmatic traction.81 The fact that many critical care teams inappropriately use PN as the sole route of nutrition support when the enteral route is available66 argues in favor of a simple paradigm that distinguishes between PN and EN solely on the basis of their route of administration, boiling the issue down to an extremely simple, easy-to-remember clinical dictum.

sec.title: An Appropriate Paradigm for Evidence-Based Nutrition
sec.p: The maturation of EBM over the past 2 decades is one of the most important developments in modern medicine.109,130,131 One of the current challenges for EBM is to find ways to broaden its application beyond the simple model of clinical pharmacology that it is embedded in.132 For its part, clinical nutrition faces the challenge of finding ways to reengineer an EBM practice paradigm that is embedded in pharmacology to make it applicable to the more complex physiological paradigm required for clinical nutrition. Concepts that are more important in (or crucial to) clinical nutrition but less important (or absent) from a pharmacology-embedded paradigm include the notion of deficiency,133 average vs safe nutrient requirements, variable dose-response relationships for different nutrients, multiple complex nutrient interactions, and wide biological heterogeneity.134,135 (For example, the majority of vitamin D studies included in recent meta-analyses of the benefits of vitamin D supplementation failed to take into account the fact that people who are not deficient in a nutrient cannot be expected to benefit nutritionally from taking supplements of it.136)

Given the theoretical and practical difficulties involved in gathering the kind of RCT evidence for nutrients that would be required to license a drug for a specific therapeutic indication,137 it is safe to assume that large gray zones will continue to pervade clinical nutrition for a long time to come. Consequently, physiologically insightful paradigm-embedded reasoning will continue to play a far more important role in clinical nutrition than it does in clinical pharmacology. Biological, observational, and metabolic data will continue to serve the crucial functions of informing clinical judgment and identifying the most important clinical hypotheses for eventual testing by RCTs.138 There is no way to avoid this laborious and time-consuming scientific activity, even as it is carried out with a sober appreciation that the conclusions reached are necessarily more provisional than conclusions drawn from an unbiased selection of high-quality, pertinent RCTs with comparable and consistent findings.

sec.title: What Makes Guidelines Easy to Ignore
sec.p: It is not the clinician’s job to treat every patient like the group average in a meta-analysis of RCTs.132,139 Guidelines are most useful when they provide a set of coherent and persuasive guiding principles that can be used as the basis for reasoning and making individual clinical decisions.109,130,131,140 Guidelines that lack a persuasive conceptual paradigm will lack narrative flow, and from the psychological point of view, this lack makes them easy to ignore and forget. Nowhere is a sound paradigm more important than in clinical nutrition. Ignorance of the principles of nutrition—and its differences from pharmacology—is rampant among health care workers.141 Guidelines also have to “make sense” to clinicians trained in nutrition, because otherwise they will base their decisions on personal experience and potentially biased clinical judgment, rather than on the evidence presented in guidelines.142

Reasons why many critical care specialists ignore current guideline recommendations regarding artificial nutrition may be inferred from the chapter on nutrition support in a recent excellent textbook of critical care medicine.143 This chapter explains that although chronic starvation certainly leads to poor outcomes, it is well known that healthy people tolerate several days without food. The chapter authors concede that nutrition support is important for patients with preexisting “nutrition deficiencies” or a prolonged stay in the ICU but point out that the great majority of patients appear to be well nourished and their stays are brief. The bottom line is that there is little very strong evidence that nutrition support improves important clinical outcomes for most critically ill patients, whereas artificial feeding of any kind is complicated, time-consuming, and prone to serious complications. The overall strength of the RCT evidence that nutrition regimens in current use actually improve clinical outcomes is considered debatable.60,74,122,144-146

Critical care specialists are aware of the plain fact that most of their patients have adequate or excessive fat stores. What they do not realize is that adequate fat is no guarantee of an adequate lean tissue reserve. Consequently, they fail to appreciate that many (perhaps most) of their patients could benefit from early and adequate protein provision. They are skeptical of the recommendation to provide calories to fully maintain their patients’ already generous fat stores. In this skepticism, they are entirely correct.

sec.title: What Research Needs to Be Done?
sec.p: Recent RCTs of metabolic or nutrition interventions in critical illness have been grossly deficient in protein.56,147 The time is long overdue to launch insightfully designed and appropriately targeted RCTs to test the hypothesis that early and sufficient amino acid supplementation of inadequate EN can improve the clinical outcome of many critically ill patients. Preliminary studies with intensive EN protocols offer the possibility of delivering approximately 1.2 g protein/kg normalized body weight per day after approximately 3 days.148 Unfortunately, even this labor-intensive procedure falls well short of the optimum time frame and rate of protein provision, which could well be 2.0 g/kg/d or more for a large proportion of critically ill patients.11,121 A more straightforward design would compare the grossly protein-deficient “permissive underfeeding” regimen now recommended in the A.S.P.E.N. guidelines with the same regimen supplemented by early and suitably generous hypocaloric intravenous amino acids, with appropriate downward adjustments as enteral carbohydrate and protein provision increase toward the preselected high-protein hypocaloric target. Outcomes of particular interest could be ventilatory status, since starvation decreases ventilatory responsiveness and amino acid infusions increase it,149,150 and the number and duration of serious infections, given the known roles of dietary protein in immune function and wound healing.

Certain pitfalls will have to be avoided when designing these studies. Patients who are not critically ill should not be enrolled, for they might require no more than 0.8 g protein/kg/d. Patients clinically judged to be at high risk of liver failure or who have refractory hypotension or overwhelming sepsis should be excluded, since even very large amounts of protein are unlikely to reverse their immediate clinical course and could be toxic. Patients with hypoaminoacidemia and markedly increased urinary urea excretion151 could be the most suitable for enrollment in initial, dose-finding clinical trials, as they are experiencing more severe protein catabolism and are the most likely to demonstrate a robust beneficial response to sufficiently generous protein provision.

Since protein intake calculations are based on body weight—an unreliable surrogate for the lean tissue store in critical illness84,85,152,153—it will be essential to use an explicit, practical rule for estimating a patient’s body weight appropriately corrected for volume expansion and excess adipose tissue. One empirical rule has been suggested and used, namely, the arithmetic average of ideal and measured body weight in “severely malnourished” patients and 20% greater than ideal body weight in obese patients.56,154 It would be just as rational, and simpler, to calculate the body weight that corresponds to a BMI of 23. Patients whose existing BMI is <18 or >35 should probably not be enrolled in preliminary clinical trials because calculation of the protein requirement as a linear function of even well-adjusted body weight is inaccurate at the extremes of obesity and underweight.79

sec.title: Summary and Recommendations
sec.p: This analysis offers several reasons why the question of optimal protein provision has been almost completely ignored in the critical care literature, research, and clinical practice. The fundamental explanation appears to be a widespread failure to reason coherently about human protein and energy metabolism within the framework of a physiologically sound paradigm, a problem considerably worsened by the almost impenetrable barrier to reasoning created by the multitude of ambiguous and sometimes contradictory definitions of malnutrition in the critical care literature. These factors explain, but do not scientifically justify, the current preoccupation with “calorie” goals while mostly ignoring the need to identify and target appropriate goals for protein provision. We offer the following suggestions to address this problem.

The section in nutrition care guidelines dealing with energy and protein provision should include a description of the pathophysiology of protein and energy deficiency and the protein-catabolic effects of critical illness. The practices recommended in guidelines should be consistent with known biology or, at a minimum, acknowledge conflicts. Practices that contradict biological plausibility should be regarded as suspect.113 Specifically, the biologically unjustified preoccupation in the current literature with short-term calorie provision to maintain the fat reserve of fat-replete, protein-deficient patients, while ignoring or downplaying protein provision, needs to be redirected.

Language regarding “malnutrition” needs to be cleaned up. Careful distinction should be made between diagnosis, screening, and risk prediction for they are important, but different, areas of investigation and clinical practice. The biologically crucial distinction between “permissive underfeeding” (global starvation of protein, energy, and micronutrients) and “hypocaloric nutrition” (deliberate energy restriction with a compensatory increase in protein provision) needs to be acknowledged and explained.

There is an urgent need for appropriately designed critical trials to identify the optimal level of protein provision in critical illness, even if their design goes against current anti-PN strictures by involving low-calorie, high amino acid parenteral mixtures.
